headline.print_headline: Regular Marijuana Use by High School Students Hits New Peak, Report Finds

docs.abstract: Marijuana use among teenagers has reached a 30-year peak even as use of alcohol, cigarettes and cocaine continues a slow decline, according to a new government report.
docs.snippet: Marijuana use among teenagers has reached a 30-year peak even as use of alcohol, cigarettes and cocaine continues a slow decline, according to a new government report.

docs.lead_paragraph: Production problems have disrupted treatment plans. Experts advise patients to take a number of practical steps.

headline.seo: The Personal Price Paid for Shortages of Doxil and Other Drugs
headline.main: Drug Scarcity’s Dire Cost, and Some Ways to Cope
headline.print_headline: Drug Scarcity’s Dire Cost, And Some Ways to Cope

docs.abstract: More than 251 drugs were in short supply in 2011, including 20 chemotherapy agents, according to study by American Society of Health-System Pharmacists; scarcity drives up health care costs as hospitals turn to more expensive substitutes, and increases risk of medical errors and complications; consumers are advised to be more proactive regarding their medications in order to protect themselves; shortages are due in a large part to reduction in number of factories producing drugs and price spikes caused by unethical distributors who take advantage of panic.
docs.snippet: Production problems have disrupted treatment plans. Experts advise patients to take a number of practical steps.

docs.lead_paragraph: Patients had a lower risk of renal failure, a shorter stay in the intensive care unit and a reduced risk of major cardiac problems, a study found.

headline.seo: Aspirin May Have Benefits Before Heart Surgery
headline.main: Regimens: Aspirin’s Benefits Before Heart Surgery
headline.print_headline: Regimen: Aspirin’s Benefits Before Heart Surgery

docs.abstract: Study published in the Annals of Surgery finds that benefits of taking aspirin in week before heart surgery outweighs the risk, contradicting current guidelines; study's lead author is Jianzhong Sun of Jefferson Medical College.
docs.snippet: Patients had a lower risk of renal failure, a shorter stay in the intensive care unit and a reduced risk of major cardiac problems, a study found.

docs.lead_paragraph: Women who drank four or more cups of coffee a day are at reduced risk of endometrial cancer, a large new study found.

headline.seo: Four Daily Cups of Coffee May Cut Cancer Risk in Women
headline.main: Patterns: Coffee May Help Cut Cancer Risk in Women
headline.print_headline: Patterns: Coffee May Help Cut Cancer Risk in Women

docs.abstract: Large study published online in journal Cancer Epidemiology, Biomarkers & Prevention finds women who drink four or more cups of coffee a day are at reduced risk of endometrial cancer; Youjin Je, a doctoral student at the Harvard School of Public Health, is study's lead author.
docs.snippet: Women who drank four or more cups of coffee a day are at reduced risk of endometrial cancer, a large new study found.

docs.lead_paragraph: The World Health Organization estimates that snakebites kill between 20,000 and 94,000 people a year, though some experts consider this estimate too low.

headline.seo: Public Health Experts Calls for a New Emphasis on Snakebite
headline.main: Snakebite: Experts Seek New Emphasis on Quiet Killer
headline.print_headline: Snakebite: Experts Seek New Emphasis on Quiet Killer

docs.abstract: Two papers arguing for a new emphasis on combating snakebite deaths worldwide are presented at the annual meeting of the American Society of Tropical Medicine and Hygiene; the World Health Organization estimates that snakebites kill between 20,000 and 94,000 people a year, though some experts consider this estimate too low.
docs.snippet: The World Health Organization estimates that snakebites kill between 20,000 and 94,000 people a year, though some experts consider this estimate too low.

docs.lead_paragraph: While the number of obese babies is not on the rise, some of our standard infant feeding practices and attitudes may need revising.

headline.main: The Joy of Feeding, Without All the Parental Angst
headline.print_headline: The Joy of Feeding, Without All the Parental Angst

docs.abstract: Experts on child nutrition have begun to criticize age-old parental wisdom that hearty eating is always a good thing in infants, especially in environment of abundant food and rising obesity; one promising line of research involves training parents to recognize signals of hunger and satiety in their infants.
docs.snippet: While the number of obese babies is not on the rise, some of our standard infant feeding practices and attitudes may need revising.

docs.lead_paragraph: Nearly every woman I know can recall one or more instances in which she was sexually assaulted, harassed, threatened, inappropriately touched or even raped.
docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column asserts that today, despite improvements in early sex education and widespread publicity about sexual assaults, the overwhelming majority of both federal and misdemeanor cases never come to public or legal attention; notes that 15 of 16 rapists will never spend time in jail.
docs.snippet: Nearly every woman I know can recall one or more instances in which she was sexually assaulted, harassed, threatened, inappropriately touched or even raped.

docs.lead_paragraph: The policy conceit that spending money on patients who die is a waste overlooks the core purpose of health care.

headline.main: When Care Is Worth It, Even if End Is Death
headline.print_headline: When Care Is Worth It, Even if End Is Death

docs.abstract: Dr Peter R Bach essay questions popular notion that excessive health care is wasted on terminal patients; says policy makers who rely too heavily on metrics that judge hospital performance by amount of 'wasted' treatments are missing the core purpose of health care.
docs.snippet: The policy conceit that spending money on patients who die is a waste overlooks the core purpose of health care.
